componenttextpreview: I was just wondering, so given the strong demand trends, especially in the Industrial and Automotive, how are you seeing pricing trends. I'm wondering if you have anything to comment on that.
componenttext: I was just wondering, so given the strong demand trends, especially in the Industrial and Automotive, how are you seeing pricing trends. I'm wondering if you have anything to comment on that.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: I'd say there's really nothing special happening on the pricing trends. We've -- we always find that we -- when we develop products that give the performance that customers need and want, then you got more pricing power than when you make commodity-type p
componenttext: I'd say there's really nothing special happening on the pricing trends. We've -- we always find that we -- when we develop products that give the performance that customers need and want, then you got more pricing power than when you make commodity-type prices. So in general, though, our view has been that the pricing in the -- in most of the markets, frankly, has stabilized a lot more because there's more demand for semiconductors. And not us, but some other companies might be having difficulty producing everything, so that all helps. And some of the consolidation, obviously, has helped as well. So from a pricing standpoint, I think the trends are good. They're in favor of high-performance companies, and we definitely are one of these companies. So I think there's really not much special happening there.

componenttext: Yes, so still a lot of work being done there. And so if you look at the difference between the first half of our fiscal year, it will be a 35%. The second half will be at 21%. So on a weighted average, you sort of come down to a 28%. So that's been the benefit there.

componenttext: Yes. So I think in general, if we think about our business, the Consumer business, as we become more broad-based, those parts of the business are usually stronger in the second half of the year. There's usually more product launches in that time of the year. And so I think that is something we'll take a look at. Usually, Industrial is down and Automotive is flat. Both of those businesses are doing very well right now. And so I think in general, right, that could be a little upward bias, but it's really too early to tell. And then as I said, I think from the Comm and Data Center, we don't have insights on the infrastructure side, and I think optical is going to continue to grow very strongly.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Latif. Welcome, everyone, to Maxim Integrated's Fiscal Fourth Quarter 2018 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Tunç Doluca; and Chief Financial Officer, Bruce Kiddoo.I would like to highlight t
componenttext:
Thank you, Latif. Welcome, everyone, to Maxim Integrated's Fiscal Fourth Quarter 2018 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Tunç Doluca; and Chief Financial Officer, Bruce Kiddoo.
I would like to highlight that we posted a supplemental financial presentation to our external Investor Relations website. The information in this presentation accompanies the financial disclosures in our earnings press release and on this conference call. During today's call, we will be making some forward-looking statements. In light of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act, I would like to remind you that these statements must be considered in conjunction with the cautionary warnings that appear in our SEC filings. Investors are cautioned that all forward-looking statements in this call involve risks and security and that future events may differ materially from the statements made. For additional information, please refer to the company's Securities and Exchange Commission filings, which are posted on our website.
Now, I'll turn the call over to Tunç.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathy. Good afternoon to all our participants, and thank you for joining us today. We appreciate your interest in Maxim Integrated. We're pleased with our June quarter results. Our power management franchise in Automotive and Industrial is prod
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathy. Good afternoon to all our participants, and thank you for joining us today. We appreciate your interest in Maxim Integrated. We're pleased with our June quarter results. Our power management franchise in Automotive and Industrial is producing sustainable and profitable growth. Our growing free cash flow enables us to announce a 10% increase in our dividend today, delivering long-term value to our shareholders. 
Let me next turn to this quarter's results. Compared to the same quarter last year, revenue grew strongly driven by Automotive, Industrial and Data Center with continued solid profitability. I would like to remind investors that June quarter last year included a transition of Digi-Key to accounting. During my market revenu commentary, I will exclude this factor. First, I will comment on Automotive. In the June quarter, our Automotive business was up 20% from the same quarter last year. We continued to see strong demand in Automotive power products for entertainment systems, management systems for electric vehicles and driver-assistance content. Our expertise in Automotive Safety Integrity Level's, also known as ASIL, is a key competitive advantage in our power and battery management products. As I mentioned last quarter, these safety levels address potential hazards that can occur when electrical systems in cars malfunction.
Maxim's battery management system and power management products for Automotive lead the industry in ASIL performance. In the quarter, we announced several new products to address the specific power management requirements for driver assistance applications, such as collision avoidance, navigation, adaptive cruise control, Lane centering, Lane departure warning and vision cameras. Power management comprises over half of Maxim's dollar content opportunities in driver-assistance applications. 
Turning to the September quarter. We expect Automotive to be flat sequentially, in line with seasonality and up in the high-teens from the same quarter last year. We expect strength from content growth and infotainment, battery management systems and driver assistance. 
Let me next turn to the Industrial market. In the June quarter, Industrial was strongly up 13% from the same quarter last year, after normalizing for accounting in last year's baseline. Our growth in Industrial was led by overall strong distribution resales in the broad market by factory automation content and in medical products. In our broad market business, we continued to grow resales through our distribution partners. In the quarter, we added a new distribution partner in Asia, as we extend our global customer reach, particularly to small and medium business customers. In the June quarter, distribution channel resales grew 17% from the same period last year. This is healthy double-digit growth from a strong 2017 June quarter. In factory automation, Maxim customers are enabling intelligence at the edge of the factory network. We're in the early days of the deployment of industry 4.0 control systems in factories around the world. And this movement has a few more decades before the market saturates. Maxim has content in controllers, sensors and an opportunity in robuts. As controllers and sensors become more complex, the engineering requirements grow, and our content opportunity grows as well. We estimate that Maxim's content opportunities in controllers can double and sensor content can grow by 50% with the implementation of a modern industry 4.0 factory architecture.
In Medical, we continued to see double-digit year-over-year growth from a small revenue base in authentication and ultrasound products. Our authentication products ensure that genuine medical consumables are used with clinical equipment. We expect continued growth of this business over the coming quarters. In the September quarter, we expect Industrial to be down sequentially in line with seasonality and up in the mid-teens, again, compared to the same period last year. This performance is expected to be led by factory automation products and through our strategy to reach small and medium business customers with distribution partners. 
Let me next discuss Communications and Data Center. In the June quarter, Comm and Data Center was up sequentially with strong growth in 100G optical products for the Data Center. In the September quarter, we anticipate Comms and Data Center revenue to be flat sequentially, and up strongly from the same period last year. Our year-over-year growth is expected to be driven by deployments of 100G optical products for high-speed rack-to-rack connectivity within Data Centers.
Finally, let me turn to Consumer. Consumer was strongly down sequentially in the June quarter as expected and was modestly up from the same period a year ago. Diversification in tablets, variables, gaming and a broad set of consumer products enabled our growth from the same quarter last year. We continued to execute on a broad market strategy with small, medium business customers in the Consumer market. In the quarter, we announced few products that provide industry-leading accuracy in battery management for a range of applications, including handheld gaming systems, smartphone devices and USB Type-C affordable devices. Looking forward to the September quarter, we expect Consumer to be strongly up sequentially and flat from the same quarter last year through diversification in tablets and gaming. Smartphones are expected to be flat sequentially.
To summarize, current business conditions are good and we built Maxim to be successful in any environment. One, we're growing in high-quality diversified markets such as Automotive and Industrial. Two, our flexible manufacturing structure ensures consistent world-class gross margins. Three, we continue to tight spending controls. And four, we have low capital intensity in manufacturing. All of this is driving strong and predictable cash flows. Maxim priorities are to grow revenue, maximize profitability with continued financial stability and we are certainly delivering on all three. With that, I'll now turn the call over to you, Bruce.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tunç. Revenue for Q4 was $633 million, up 5% from the same quarter a year ago or up 9% after adjusting for the sound accounting transition in Q4 '17. Our revenue mix by major markets in Q4 was approximately 30% from Industrial, 24% Consumer, 22%
componenttext:
Thanks, Tunç. Revenue for Q4 was $633 million, up 5% from the same quarter a year ago or up 9% after adjusting for the sound accounting transition in Q4 '17. Our revenue mix by major markets in Q4 was approximately 30% from Industrial, 24% Consumer, 22% Automotive, 20% common Data Center and 4% computing. Our Industrial and Automotive business is comprised over 50% of our revenue in the quarter.
Let me now turn to the distribution channel. Distribution comprised 51% of Maxim's revenue in the June quarter. We ended Q4 with 60 days of inventory in the distribution channel within our target range of 55 to 60 days. Our delivery lead times are still 5 to 7 weeks and have been in this range for over 6 years. We continue to closely manage our supply chain and our distributors performance given the uncertainties in the industry. 
Turning to the P&L. Maxim's gross margin, excluding special items, was 68%, up from the prior quarter with the increase driven by ongoing tailwinds and a few one-time items. Operating expenses, excluding special items, were $195 million, down slightly from the prior quarter, reflecting continued cost controls. Q4 GAAP operating income, excluding special items, was $236 million. Operating margin at 37.2% of revenue is up from the prior quarter and up 140 basis points from the same quarter a year ago. Q4 GAAP tax rate, excluding special items, was 12%. GAAP earnings per share, excluding special items, was $0.73, up 17% from the same quarter a year ago. For the full fiscal year, 2018 EPS grew 28% year-over-year. 
Turning to the balance sheet and cash flow. Overall, total cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments decreased by $98 million in the fourth quarter to $2.63 billion. Q4 inventory days ended at 127, up 10 days from Q3. Inventory dollars were up 3% from the prior quarter.
Capital expenditures were $12 million in the quarter. Trailing 12-month free cash flow was $932 million or 38% of revenue, which is up 29% over the same quarter last year. Free cash flow excludes a onetime tax payment of $178 million related to a preliminary understanding with the IRF. Our free cash flow yield is 5.6% at yesterday's closing stock price. Our free cash flow per share was $3.28, above our original target of $3 per share and well on our way to our current target of $3.50 per share.
For capital return, share repurchases totaled $128 million in Q4, as we bought back approximately 2.2 million shares. Dividends totaled $117 million in the quarter or $0.42 per share. As Tunç mentioned, our board has approved a 10% increase in the dividend, which will be paid in Q1 '19. Based on the increase in the dividend and yesterday's closing stock price, our dividend yield is just over 3%. Our increase in the dividend plus share repurchases reflect our return of capital commitment of 100% of free cash flow. 
Moving on to guidance. Our beginning Q1 backlog was $441 million. Based on this beginning backlog and expected turns, we forecast Q1 revenue of $615 million to $655 million. Q1 revenue is expected to be up approximately 10% at the midpoint of our guidance compared to the same quarter last year, driven by double-digit growth in Automotive and Industrial. Q1 gross margin, excluding special items, is forecasted at 66.5% to 68.5%, down slightly due to the one-time items from the prior quarter. Q1 operating expenses, excluding special items, are expected to be in the mid-190s, flat with Q4 despite the impact of our annual merit increase in September due to continued tight cost controls. Our tax rate for Q1, excluding special items, is expected to be 9% to 10%, down from Q4 due to tax reform and the preliminary understanding with the IRS. For Q1, GAAP earnings per share, excluding special items, we expect a range of $0.72 to $0.78. For FY '19, we expect capital expenditures to be at the high end of our targeted range of 1% to 3% of revenue, as we perform required maintenance and add capacity to our only remaining internal fab. 
In summary, we expect significant growth in Q1 revenue compared to the same quarter last year, led by growth in Automotive and Industrial. Our financial model is a hallmark of high-quality companies, delivering strong earnings and free cash flow growth, a 100% of which we are returning to shareholders. With that, I'll turn the call back over to Kathy.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] First question comes from Harlan Sur from JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] First question comes from Harlan Sur from JPMorgan.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Good job on the quarterly execution and strong free cash flow generation. Great job on the gross margin expansion and the move towards the upper end of your target of 70%. I think, you guys beat the June quarter guidance by 100 basis points, the midpoint.
componenttext: Good job on the quarterly execution and strong free cash flow generation. Great job on the gross margin expansion and the move towards the upper end of your target of 70%. I think, you guys beat the June quarter guidance by 100 basis points, the midpoint. And it looks like your September quarter outlook shows the sustainability of those margins. I remember at our investor conference back in May, you guys articulated some near-term initiatives you're focused on to drive gross margins and namely that was improving the utilizations of your internal organ fab, which has a lower cost profile and moving more products into that fab. Is that what drove the margin expansion on part of the margin expansion? And maybe if you can just articulated some of the other initiatives both near-term and longer term?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Hi, Harlan. Thanks for the question. Your remembering is good. When we did talk about the tailwinds, one of them was the increased utilization of our remaining fab up in Organ. We also talked about flexible boundary capacity in our ability to move wafers
componenttext: Hi, Harlan. Thanks for the question. Your remembering is good. When we did talk about the tailwinds, one of them was the increased utilization of our remaining fab up in Organ. We also talked about flexible boundary capacity in our ability to move wafers around to kind of optimize cost on that. Of course, deposition will continue to come down towards CapEx. Depreciation was $23 million in the quarter and CapEx was like $12 million, $13 million. And then we also talked about growth in our SMB customer rates and sort of the growth in our kind of the change in mix of our business, and finally the improving pricing environment. So when we look at Q4, of those tailwinds, probably the most pronounced was this improvement in our Digi-Key business. It was over 51% of revenue, right? So that continues to grow. And we know that a high-margin business. In addition, Industrial was 30% of revenue. I didn't check it, but I think my time has been here, that's close to a high water mark for Industrial. So again -- so I think that strategy of going for high-quality businesses and going for SMB is also adding to that gross margin. So I think going forward, every quarter we were not going to have all of those tailwinds help. I think in this case it was SMB and the push into Industrial and Automotive. I think we will continue to see those tailwinds and help us continue to grow our gross margin overtime, including that a whole earliest. I will say that, for onetime items that helped us a little bit in Q4. And so that's why we guided Q1, the September quarter, down a little bit. We only guide in kind of 50 bps increments. And so kind of the midpoint of our guidance came out to about 67.5%. We'll probably do a little bit better than that. But it will be down. We are expecting to be down a little bit just because of some of those one-time items. But overall, I think, just the continued movement up of gross margin. And as we've always said, it won't happen and in some big chunk it's just going to be nice incremental tailwinds over multiple years to really drive to the upper end of that 67% to 70% range.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Seymore of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Seymore of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: You guys are doing great on the Industrial and Automotive side, and I don't think that shouldn't surprise to anyone anymore. But the consumer side, I know it's volatile given with your handset -- your primary handset customer does. But the guidance going
componenttext: You guys are doing great on the Industrial and Automotive side, and I don't think that shouldn't surprise to anyone anymore. But the consumer side, I know it's volatile given with your handset -- your primary handset customer does. But the guidance going forward, a bit stronger than I would have expected. Tunç mentioned a couple of product areas. But can you just go into a little more specific on what's driving that upside? And then as you look longer term, how important is that Consumer business to your strategy overall?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sure. So what's really happened a couple of years back, we've decided that we have to broaden this business new customers in addition to the ones we had and find new applications where our products could go. Basically, we've been executing on their strate
componenttext: Sure. So what's really happened a couple of years back, we've decided that we have to broaden this business new customers in addition to the ones we had and find new applications where our products could go. Basically, we've been executing on their strategy. And as a result, we've had a lot of product areas where we can sell our parts outside of smartphones in addition to smartphones. These are products like gaming systems, they are variables, they are hearable, any talked a lot of those also in the past. So all of those other non-smartphone applications that we made products are basically paying dividends now. And as you saw, we were able to have, despite strong headwind because of the actually re-ramp from our major customer, year-over-year we did pretty well in that space. So in the long-term, we're going to continue to look for applications where we can have sustainable differentiation, and we can command what type of margins we can. And when we found those applications, we will invest in those. But in the long-term, one of your questions, what do you expect for growth? We're really not counting on much of a growth in the Consumer space. So I think, future growth is still going to be mostly coming from Automotive and Industrial, as you mentioned, with the Data Center -- the cloud Data Center being the third and very modest growth in Consumer.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ambrish Srivastava of BMO of Montreal.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ambrish Srivastava of BMO of Montreal.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Pretty solid execution, guys. I had a question on the -- do you just help us understand the business conditions? And you mentioned some of the cyclical indicators lead times and channel inventory. But maybe just provide us with some perspective on what ar
componenttext: Pretty solid execution, guys. I had a question on the -- do you just help us understand the business conditions? And you mentioned some of the cyclical indicators lead times and channel inventory. But maybe just provide us with some perspective on what are you seeing overall versus a year ago? And I know, Bruce, last quarter, you had addressed you have gone out of your way address concerned about double ordering. So anything on those lines on the cyclicals would be great?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: So I think, we thought this question would come up. So I think in my prepared remarks, I basically said that the business conditions are good. We look at multiple things to understand this. We explained some of that in the last call as well. So I'll repea
componenttext: So I think, we thought this question would come up. So I think in my prepared remarks, I basically said that the business conditions are good. We look at multiple things to understand this. We explained some of that in the last call as well. So I'll repeat those. We do look at the ordering patterns of our customers, and our ability to meet those orders. That's usually the first thing that triggers customers getting concerned and placing extra orders, let's say. So in Maxim's case, we're aware that there is a lot of shortages of other components. But in Maxim's case, our customer order lead times, the lead time at which they order from us, has really not changed appreciably. That's #1. #2 is, our ability to respond and deliver to their orders has not changed for us and has been in this 5 to 7-week range for 5 to 6 years. So we don't see any reason for them to change the way they order from the company. We also look at other indicators. We look at cancellations -- order cancellations and indicators. We look at pushouts of orders. That's another indicator. So when we look at all these, we're seeing things to be normal and we're happy to see the fact that the business conditions are good. And we're growing the broad base business for the company. So those comments that we made also last quarter, none of those have changed this quarter. So it looks the same way.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: This is on for Craig. I just wanted to ask if you could speak a bit technology updates on the BMS front? Just where you are seeing trajectory and growth in terms of geographies for BMS products?
componenttext: This is on for Craig. I just wanted to ask if you could speak a bit technology updates on the BMS front? Just where you are seeing trajectory and growth in terms of geographies for BMS products?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the BMS product line for us has been doing really well. We actually -- we're happy to see that we're getting a lot of design wins -- continuing to get a lot of design wins. It is -- wv got design wins at 28 OEMs and counting. And we have now over
componenttext: Sure. So the BMS product line for us has been doing really well. We actually -- we're happy to see that we're getting a lot of design wins -- continuing to get a lot of design wins. It is -- wv got design wins at 28 OEMs and counting. And we have now over 80 models. I think, we said 70 in the last call or the call even before that. We have more models now where we have design wins. A lot of the business is showing up in our China accounts. But the recent wins have been in other regions as well, both in Europe and in the U.S. And we're shipping really to every geographical region. So it's pretty broad-based. The China EV demand can be lumpy, but the opportunity is real given that there are quality issue that we all hear about in China. We do expect the market is growing at least 2x faster than the rest of Automotive, which is good and healthy. We look at our numbers and the year-over-year basis we've almost doubled this business year-over-year. So conditions are very good. And the reason it looks like we are winning these customers is that, same thing I talked about in my prepared remarks. They really like our, which is a safety we talked about specification in a single quarter they don't have the bill this whole system for safety. Our part does it on its own. They like that and as a result they design our products in.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Great, that's helpful. Thank you. Just looking at kind of like your third dividend increase in the past year, how are you thinking about the balance between buybacks and dividends moving forward?
componenttext: Great, that's helpful. Thank you. Just looking at kind of like your third dividend increase in the past year, how are you thinking about the balance between buybacks and dividends moving forward?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So this is Bruce, I'll take that. I think, overall when we think about our return to capital policy, we returned about 100%. Our commitment is to return 100% of free cash flow to shareholders. When we think about the split between the 2, it really ki
componenttext: Yes. So this is Bruce, I'll take that. I think, overall when we think about our return to capital policy, we returned about 100%. Our commitment is to return 100% of free cash flow to shareholders. When we think about the split between the 2, it really kind of starts with the dividend and we look at that as a -- on a free cash flow payout ratio. And we generally tried to target about 50% payout ratio on the dividend, and with the idea being that we always want to make sure that if there is some type of global cycle that no matter what happens to our business that dividend will be safe. I think the good news is and what gives us confidence is, not only is our business doing very well, but the company is structured to do very well in any type of environment. And so when we think about that obviously, we're growing in these high-quality diversified markets markets, Automotive, Industrial. Since the last recession, we shifted our manufacturing strategy, where back in 2008 I think we were like 85%, 90% in-house, now we're only 25% in-house. So we have a much better variable cost structure. Obviously, we continued to manage our spending tightly. CapEx is within a very narrow range of 1% to 3%. And so all of that drives these very strong cash flows and very consistent cash flows. And so because of that, management and the board is confident in increasing the dividend. I'd say the other thing is, normally we do it at this time frame. We did do an increase in January because that was because of tax reform and we got access to all of our International cash. So that further gave us -- so at that time we increased the dividends 17%, and now we're increasing another 10%. Again, based on the strength of the business, sort of the model we built, that we think can be successful in any environment and the availability of 100% of our cash. And so those are the factors that are really thinking or how we think of the dividend and overall return of capital.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Toshiya Hari of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Toshiya Hari of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Your infotainment business within Automotive, last time, I checked in, I think it was about 2/3 of your business. Your Automotive business continues to grow at a very nice clip. I think, your peers infotainment are growing at a much slower late. So just c
componenttext: Your infotainment business within Automotive, last time, I checked in, I think it was about 2/3 of your business. Your Automotive business continues to grow at a very nice clip. I think, your peers infotainment are growing at a much slower late. So just curious what's driving the outperformance there? Is it more a function of things like BMS outside of infotainment driving the overall growth in Automotive or are there specific things to your infotainment business that's driving the upside?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: So your numbers are about right. So infotainment is roughly little bit less than 2/3 of our Automotive business now, and it continues to grow in the low double-digits. And I think that, obviously, the other 2, you mentioned, BMS and ADAS, those products a
componenttext: So your numbers are about right. So infotainment is roughly little bit less than 2/3 of our Automotive business now, and it continues to grow in the low double-digits. And I think that, obviously, the other 2, you mentioned, BMS and ADAS, those products are in hyper growth, and they are from a smaller base. So that's more understandable. Actually I'm not aware of what everybody else is reporting for infotainment. But I mean, if you're saying we are growing faster, that's good, means our products are better. I don't really have a much better explanation. The thing that one reason that I can speculate about was our capabilities some of these products, which are important. And our revenue in infotainment comes mostly from power. And I'm not sure what the makeup is for these other companies that are reporting in infotainment. And I think, the power needs might be growing faster than other functions or other systems infotainment. So those are kind of speculative that we really don't have the exact data to support that. But that would be my estimation.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Blayne Curtis of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Blayne Curtis of Barclays.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask a 100G has been a big driver for you. It's grown sequentially over the last several quarters. The flat guidance. I'm just curious what your outlook for 100G into the back half of the calendar year. Is there any offset in. There's defini
componenttext: Just wanted to ask a 100G has been a big driver for you. It's grown sequentially over the last several quarters. The flat guidance. I'm just curious what your outlook for 100G into the back half of the calendar year. Is there any offset in. There's definitely been some commentary about 100G being strong fairly. So one hyperscale guy. And then just quickly on the tax rate. I wanted to understand is that for the fiscal year or just this quarter?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: I'll quickly answer the 100G. So we're doing well in 100G. As we've said in earlier calls, our strength is mostly in the laser driver side so the Data Center and the 100G business. From a year-over-year basis, I think we continue to see growth in fiscal y
componenttext: I'll quickly answer the 100G. So we're doing well in 100G. As we've said in earlier calls, our strength is mostly in the laser driver side so the Data Center and the 100G business. From a year-over-year basis, I think we continue to see growth in fiscal year '19 compared to '18. And in the visibility right now is that far, obviously, we're working on the next-generation products. But I think for the next couple of years, maybe 3 years, most of it will be coming from 100G products. And we've got wins that spend multiple club customers. So I don't know comment was from which one. But I think when you see a 100G intra Data Center growth, we're most likely involved in that design win or in that business.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: And then from a tax rate point of view. We did say 9 -- guided 9% to 10% for Q1, but that's also a good number to use for the full fiscal year. Obviously, we continue to understand the rules that are not all rules final yet. And so we continue to work on
componenttext: And then from a tax rate point of view. We did say 9 -- guided 9% to 10% for Q1, but that's also a good number to use for the full fiscal year. Obviously, we continue to understand the rules that are not all rules final yet. And so we continue to work on that. But from a -- from understanding what the opportunities are as a result of tax reform, we're able to manage the business such that we're comfortable with this 9% to 10% number for FY '19. And it's obviously something we continue to study and to work on in order to minimize that number.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from John Pitzer of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Next question comes from John Pitzer of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk a little bit about the Industrial. Clearly you guys are doing well there. I think, this is the first time. It's been 30% of the revenue in the June quarter. You're still kind of guiding for strong growth in September. Kathie, while back w
componenttext: I wanted to talk a little bit about the Industrial. Clearly you guys are doing well there. I think, this is the first time. It's been 30% of the revenue in the June quarter. You're still kind of guiding for strong growth in September. Kathie, while back was kind enough to kind of help educate us a little bit on the factory automation, some bucket of Industrial. And we're more intelligent on these sort of nontraditional supply chains. There has been, if you look, especially at some of the Japanese factory automation companies, some more mixed data points. I'm curious if that's something that you're seeing in the business? Is there content offset or is it just that other parts of Industrial are making up for kind of weaknesses? How do I think about factory automation growth for you guys from here?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, from our point and from talking to our customers, we believe that there is a secular growth in factory automation. What do I mean by that? What I mean really is that there is increasing animal content in the basic functions in the fact
componenttext: Well, first of all, from our point and from talking to our customers, we believe that there is a secular growth in factory automation. What do I mean by that? What I mean really is that there is increasing animal content in the basic functions in the factory like controllers and sensors, and to some extent in robotics. As intelligence moves to the edge of the factory, this was most of the presentation we gave a few months ago. And we see a lot of upgrades especially in China for their factories. And wherever precision manufacturing is needed around the world. So we have a lot of products that we designed, I would say, in the last 5, 6 years for doing better isolation products, lot of new generations of power management parts that have high voltage, which we didn't have before. And as a result of all that, we're seeing a lot of success with this freshened up product portfolio, and we're seeing that as the main driver of growth for us. So you mentioned there is something offsetting, and I'll be honest with you. I don't know what that is and we're not aware of it. But all I can say is that, I think this trend of improving their factories productivity is going to be around for a long time. And in our presentation, we showed data that say is going to be the case, especially for China and other parts of the world. So it really is a growth that's been driven by the fact that we've got these new fresh product lines that are extremely suitable for industry 4.0.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Helpful. And quick one, Bruce. You made some comments about ASPs improving. I'm wondering if that's a mix-driven ASP improvement for you or you actually starting to see some pricing power, I think you can help kind of elaborate a little bit more on that c
componenttext: Helpful. And quick one, Bruce. You made some comments about ASPs improving. I'm wondering if that's a mix-driven ASP improvement for you or you actually starting to see some pricing power, I think you can help kind of elaborate a little bit more on that comment you made in your prepared comments?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that was response to question around long-term tailwinds for gross margin. And absolutely, on a long-term basis, we think in an environment of consolidation, right, it does give some pricing power back to the chip companies, whether that's in
componenttext: Yes. I think that was response to question around long-term tailwinds for gross margin. And absolutely, on a long-term basis, we think in an environment of consolidation, right, it does give some pricing power back to the chip companies, whether that's in with our customers in BPA negotiations, whether that's in kind of the negotiations with distributors. And then, I think, also as we shift to from kind of distribution and SMB markets, right, these are smaller customers, lower volumes and generally we have more pricing power with those -- with that customer set as well. So I do think overall, we've seen a favorable pricing environment, whether that's in some areas we've been, I would say kind of manage on the longtail, be able to increase pricing and maybe with some of our larger customers that's just the smaller elections from annual price negotiation. So it is definitely a tailwind, it's not something that is easily quantified, but it's something we clearly see when we kind of look at our business year-over-year, we are able to see our product margins at kind of a constant standard cost, either stable or slightly up, which is unusual in the past. Again, those would normally come down over time.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chris Danely of Citibank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chris Danely of Citibank.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: I forgot to mention on the call earlier there was a lot of shortages out there. Can you just maybe expand upon that? What's in shortage? Is it Impacting your sales at all? And do you think this is going to get worse or get better, what can we expect this
componenttext: I forgot to mention on the call earlier there was a lot of shortages out there. Can you just maybe expand upon that? What's in shortage? Is it Impacting your sales at all? And do you think this is going to get worse or get better, what can we expect this to end?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well. We are reading, seeing reports of the extended lead times and shortages of products from other suppliers. I hope I was clear that it's -- we're not having shortages at Maxim, and we haven't had for a long time. I think, our supply chain right now is
componenttext: Well. We are reading, seeing reports of the extended lead times and shortages of products from other suppliers. I hope I was clear that it's -- we're not having shortages at Maxim, and we haven't had for a long time. I think, our supply chain right now is a lot more robust and flexible than before. So there are shortages from what I read of passive components, like capacitors and resistors, and there is still some tightness in discrete components, like and diodes, areas where you wouldn't think there would be shortages because these are easier products produce frankly than a complicated chip. But those are the ones that we've heard. Frankly, in our internal reviews, we're not hearing that that's limiting us from selling our products. Obviously, customer needs all of the bomb to be able to build something. But it's -- I've heard a very few cases where somebody said they wanted to delay shipments to Maxim products because they couldn't get something else, either they are not bubbling to me or the they are not severe enough for us to deal with. So we've really are not heard that as a reason in our forecasting reviews or internal reviews of the business.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chris Caso of Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chris Caso of Raymond James.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Just a question with regard to the distribution segment. Now 51% of revenue. Bruce, you talked about Industrial setting a new record. I guess, the question is, how long do you think that continue that distribution can grow faster than the average? How muc
componenttext: Just a question with regard to the distribution segment. Now 51% of revenue. Bruce, you talked about Industrial setting a new record. I guess, the question is, how long do you think that continue that distribution can grow faster than the average? How much more penetration get into the distribution channel, the benefits both of revenue and margin grow?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, it's hard to predict that. We don't have a specific target for distribution as a percent of overall revenue. Obviously, we're -- we push on the company to sell-through both our direct business and through distribution. And so we do expect bot
componenttext: Yes. I mean, it's hard to predict that. We don't have a specific target for distribution as a percent of overall revenue. Obviously, we're -- we push on the company to sell-through both our direct business and through distribution. And so we do expect both to kind of grow at healthy rates. And if you think of some of our businesses, like a lot of Automotive or Data Center, lot of those businesses are direct, whereas  a lot of the Industrial does go through distribution. So we push on both channels. When we do look at some of our peers, they -- if we look at their, kind of, distribution business, it can get up to 60% of revenue. So I do think there is some continued room, and we're continuing  and as tx mentioned, we added a new distribution partner in Asia. We continue to look for new partners around, kind of, the catalog-type suppliers and really selling into those really small accounts. We're also spending a lot of effort in one of the key initiatives for the company is really around digital marketing and how do we sell kind of an unassisted design wins, and whether that's just having better collateral on our website as far as application notes or simulation models, all of the items that will allow someone to find our product, pick our product, design it in with limited or no support. Of course, there's still going to be a very important role for our sales and application engineers to help those customers. But the more we can help them, get started on the process, the better. So those are all big initiative for us. So we do expect to continue to grow that business. I would expect it to go  continue to get -- as a percent of revenue to grow a little bit faster, where it ends up we don't have a specific target.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018

componenttext: Our next question comes from Muse of Evercore.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: I guess, question follow-up on the Consumer side. I only 24% of your business and now actually growing year-over-year. But curious, now that you've had a greater breadth to the customer mix there. Can you talk about kind of visibility and ability to predi
componenttext: I guess, question follow-up on the Consumer side. I only 24% of your business and now actually growing year-over-year. But curious, now that you've had a greater breadth to the customer mix there. Can you talk about kind of visibility and ability to predict business there now versus perhaps, say, 1, 2, 3 years ago? And then a quick housekeeping. Your interest expense went to break even, so should we be modeling that going forward?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: So on the Consumer side, I don't think there is that big of a change in our ability to project it in the short-term. I think longer-term projections is still not that easy to do in Consumer, because there are high-volume applications that can swing things
componenttext: So on the Consumer side, I don't think there is that big of a change in our ability to project it in the short-term. I think longer-term projections is still not that easy to do in Consumer, because there are high-volume applications that can swing things around, even outside of smartphones. So that profile has gotten a little bit better because of our exposure being not as much as it used to be to our largest customer. But I'd still say that, projecting growth or projecting revenue in Consumer 1 or 2 years out is still difficult compared to some of the other markets where design wins are pretty well known, the production ramps are pretty well known like Automotive. And it's easy to add them all up to get to a number. So it's better than before, but it's still least predictable in our markets.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Just on your house keeping question. Absolutely, we do expect that more probably be breakeven in Q1 -- in Q2. One thing to note just from a modeling point of view is, we do have $500 million in bonds that come due in November. Our current plan of record i
componenttext: Just on your house keeping question. Absolutely, we do expect that more probably be breakeven in Q1 -- in Q2. One thing to note just from a modeling point of view is, we do have $500 million in bonds that come due in November. Our current plan of record is to pay those off. So that will increase the -- or lower the interest expense. And we're paying higher  amounts on debt on that interest expense than we were earning on the cash on the balance sheet. So actually, when we get to the back half of the year, Q3, Q4, you can actually see that turn favorable by $1 million to $2 million for quarter.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chris Rolland from Susquehanna.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chris Rolland from Susquehanna.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: On for Chris Rolland. Question on Power management and the Data Center. One of your competitors has recently talked 12 volts, that's 48 volt transition on a recent conference call. Can you talk about whether you're beginning to see any inflection in in th
componenttext: On for Chris Rolland. Question on Power management and the Data Center. One of your competitors has recently talked 12 volts, that's 48 volt transition on a recent conference call. Can you talk about whether you're beginning to see any inflection in in the Data Center, and then what your outlook is for those products?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: So 48 volt distribution was we were going after for 2 or 3 years now. And we definitely have introduced our genuine products, which have some traction, and we're working on our generation 2 products. In terms of market acceptance, I think there are more c
componenttext: So 48 volt distribution was we were going after for 2 or 3 years now. And we definitely have introduced our genuine products, which have some traction, and we're working on our generation 2 products. In terms of market acceptance, I think there are more customers now interested in this distribution voltage standard, and we're certainly talking to them and showcasing our technologies. I think in terms of revenue, it's hard to predict when the first ramps will begin of these products. But so far, we've not been very successful actually predicting that ramp. And therefore, I think what we plan to do is reported when it starts rather than try and predict when it's going to start. So that's our line of record. Our products and technologies are obviously reviewed by our customers and they do like our products and technology.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018

componenttext: I just wanted to ask a follow-up question in terms of -- you mentioned you're seeing kind of more favorable pricing trends internally for your own products. I was wondering if you're seeing anything change in terms of the foundry landscape? Is capacity is going to be a little bit tighter and if there is any pressure on pricing on that front?

componenttext: Yes. So we've -- I have read some of these reports. But in the technology nodes we are in. And in our strategic foundries, which are different from reports you read, we're really not seeing neither capacity tightness or the resulting pricing pressure. So it's not something that's really affecting us.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
