componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: I wanted to dive a little bit into a similar sort of question on the Automotive side. I know you have the BMS in the ADAS side as offsets, but that business growing still 15% year-over-year is very impressive relative to a laundry list that's quite long o
componenttext: I wanted to dive a little bit into a similar sort of question on the Automotive side. I know you have the BMS in the ADAS side as offsets, but that business growing still 15% year-over-year is very impressive relative to a laundry list that's quite long of negative data points further upstream from where you guys are. So I guess any color you could give about how the company offsets some of that with content above and beyond what you already said, Tunç. And is that another shoe to fall similar to what your description of Industrial just was to the prior question?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, so if you look at the Automotive side, we have seen reports obviously of some of the Tier 1s and some of the car companies saying their growth has flattened or, in some cases, declined. But if you look at our business, we have segments of it that we'
componenttext: Yes, so if you look at the Automotive side, we have seen reports obviously of some of the Tier 1s and some of the car companies saying their growth has flattened or, in some cases, declined. But if you look at our business, we have segments of it that we've been investing in. And of those segments, I think the one that will be the most sensitive to  unit will be the infotainment piece. And we do see that, that growth is still less than it was a year ago. So the content growth is still offsetting the unit declines is the way that I read that in infotainment. And in the other segments, large segments that we've invested in, which are BMS or battery management systems and -- in ADAS, the growth there we have is much larger than any decrease in unit sales of cars. So the combination of all that is ending up giving us still a good mid-teens-type growth long-term. Previously, we've guided everybody to being in the low-teens. We're not really changing that. I think that remains. And basically, the large content growth we're seeing, plus secular growth in BMS and in ADAS systems is really letting us grow, despite the fact that there are some headwinds in terms of unit car sales globally right now. So at the current view and the view we gave of this quarter, we showed still growth year-over-year that was pretty healthy. Beyond that, obviously it's harder to say. But our story is more of a content growth and secular growth driver story in Automotive rather than the unit car sales.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Ambrish Srivastava with BMO.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Ambrish Srivastava with BMO.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Bruce, I was looking at accounts receivable, up 60%, that's a pretty large increase. I went back and looked at -- my model goes back all the way to pre-Dallas days, and I haven't seen such a big increase. So what's driving that, please?
componenttext: Bruce, I was looking at accounts receivable, up 60%, that's a pretty large increase. I went back and looked at -- my model goes back all the way to pre-Dallas days, and I haven't seen such a big increase. So what's driving that, please?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think there's a couple of things. One, just sort of the timing of the business and sort of the mix of business that we had. If you looked at this quarter, we had a strong consumer quarter, and some of those are larger customers which get a littl
componenttext: Yes. So I think there's a couple of things. One, just sort of the timing of the business and sort of the mix of business that we had. If you looked at this quarter, we had a strong consumer quarter, and some of those are larger customers which get a little bit longer payment terms. And so you had a little bit mix of that business. And if you're comparing this to year-over-year, we actually had some timing that went the other way for us a year ago in Q1. I would say that we've absolutely noticed that same fact, and we're aggressively working to bring down DSO back to kind of around the 40 days, which is our target. And you can expect that we'll execute on that. The other area in the working capital side is inventory, which we did bring down 3 days from 127 to 124 internally. But our goal is to get that down closer to our target of 110 days. And with our flexible manufacturing strategy, we're able to bring down and manage that inventory without having significant impacts to our gross margin. So we're going to aggressively manage our working capital during this kind of soft spot in the industry. And of course, just by definition, right, as revenue declines, you'll see benefits on the cash flow line from AR. So both bringing down the DSO and then the lower revenue will generate free cash flow growth for us in the next several quarters.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Vivek Arya with Bank of America, Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Vivek Arya with Bank of America, Merrill Lynch.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: On the slowdown, what are your customers saying? Have they paused certain projects and those could resume whenever the macro condition stabilizes? Or do you think they pre-bought to get in front of tariff and trade issues? And if it's the latter and there
componenttext: On the slowdown, what are your customers saying? Have they paused certain projects and those could resume whenever the macro condition stabilizes? Or do you think they pre-bought to get in front of tariff and trade issues? And if it's the latter and there is some excess inventory, is there a way to quantify how much you're above a normal level?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, so this is not that easy for us to see, frankly. Remember that, what Bruce mentioned, and we talked in our prepared remarks was, we're seeing a broad-based customer slowdown. So most of these customers are actually buying through distribution. So we'
componenttext: Yes, so this is not that easy for us to see, frankly. Remember that, what Bruce mentioned, and we talked in our prepared remarks was, we're seeing a broad-based customer slowdown. So most of these customers are actually buying through distribution. So we're 1 layer removed, actually, from the customer in their comments. If you look at a lot of our direct customers, the larger customers, that's not where we're seeing this effect. However, I'll give you some commentary. We have asked the question to some of our automation customers. And their response basically was that they are hearing that some of their end customers are kind of hesitating to build up capacity in China. I don't know how widespread that is, but we've heard it from some customers, kind of the wait and see how the tariffs clear up. But I want to caution everybody, this is not like we ran a survey and we have a lot of inputs from people, which is what a few customers are saying this. And the reason for the broad-based slowdown, since we don't directly talk to them, is really hard for us to say what the underlying cause is for that. But it could be the things that you mentioned. Maybe they do have ordered inventory ahead or so on. But we don't really know.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Bruce, just a follow-up question on distribution in terms of some of the slowing you're seeing there. Anything from a demand perspective versus inventory. So as you check into that and you've seen the orders flow, what's the feedback loop in terms of mayb
componenttext: Bruce, just a follow-up question on distribution in terms of some of the slowing you're seeing there. Anything from a demand perspective versus inventory. So as you check into that and you've seen the orders flow, what's the feedback loop in terms of maybe some slower resales versus inventory a little higher that's being worked down?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, clearly, we saw resales, which were still up 14% in the quarter, year-over-year. So that's still healthy demand. But if you sort of parse that a little bit, clearly, the very -- the smallest of those customers is through  distribution. That's
componenttext: Yes, I mean, clearly, we saw resales, which were still up 14% in the quarter, year-over-year. So that's still healthy demand. But if you sort of parse that a little bit, clearly, the very -- the smallest of those customers is through  distribution. That's where we saw, I think, a lot of the weakness. And clearly, that -- as I mentioned in the earlier question, we saw that kind of on a global basis. The slowdown also happened kind of late in the quarter. And so it's relatively new, and as Tunç just mentioned, we're trying to figure out what's going on and we're talking with our distribution partners. But it's very difficult for us to get a good handle on that. I will say, to the extent that, in certain geographies, where it's -- there's a Maxim specific story, whether that's BMS in China or Automotive in Japan or gaming in Japan, values parts of our distribution business were very strong. So automotive continues to do very well, and our broad-based consumer business is doing well also. So the real slowdown that we're seeing is mainly in kind of the industrial broad-based businesses.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Blayne Curtis with Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Blayne Curtis with Barclays.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Just kind of curious on the Comm segment. You said it pulled back and it had been strong for a couple of quarters. Just kind of curious, that should be -- I mean the 100G markets should be less cyclical. Just kind of your comments on why it's flowing back
componenttext: Just kind of curious on the Comm segment. You said it pulled back and it had been strong for a couple of quarters. Just kind of curious, that should be -- I mean the 100G markets should be less cyclical. Just kind of your comments on why it's flowing back and anything you can comment on as you look into the next couple of quarters in terms of design activity and any comments on 100G in general.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the 100G business for Maxim has been a bright spot now for the last year, 1.5 years. It has had strong growth. Our products and technology were very well accepted by customers. Nothing there has really changed in that respect. However, there are s
componenttext: Yes, so the 100G business for Maxim has been a bright spot now for the last year, 1.5 years. It has had strong growth. Our products and technology were very well accepted by customers. Nothing there has really changed in that respect. However, there are some customer issues that are unrelated to the Maxim product, that's causing them to kind of take a breather for a quarter, that's what we're hearing. So the growth has pretty much slowed down. But we really expect from what we hear from these customers that, in the first half of next calendar year, this will pick back up again and will return to growth. So nothing fundamentally has changed, but there are some customer issues that are not related to us. And those are things that they don't really like us to talk about too much. So those are good questions to the hyperscale providers, but not to Maxim. So nothing fundamentally wrong. I think it's going to be strong growth for the company long term.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Bruce, I know you talked about year-over-year growth in Auto for the December quarter. And I know there's adjustments from last year. Industrial being down strong sequentially. Does that lead to like a down mid-teens year-over-year? Am I doing those adjus
componenttext: Bruce, I know you talked about year-over-year growth in Auto for the December quarter. And I know there's adjustments from last year. Industrial being down strong sequentially. Does that lead to like a down mid-teens year-over-year? Am I doing those adjustments right for the December quarter? And if that's the case, that seems to be worse than peers. And so I'm kind of curious if you can help me kind of parse out the different buckets in Industrial. Is this really being driven by the fact that you guys are over-indexed to factory automation? And that's been an area that's been weak up the supply chain for a couple of quarters now. Or can you help me understand why you would be down more than most of your peers in that bucket?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I apologize to everyone, it's always very difficult to do that comparison with the adjustments due to Avnet in the 14th week. And so that's difficult, especially in you kind of parse it out at the sub-segment level. That said, I want to be very c
componenttext: Yes, and I apologize to everyone, it's always very difficult to do that comparison with the adjustments due to Avnet in the 14th week. And so that's difficult, especially in you kind of parse it out at the sub-segment level. That said, I want to be very clear, when we do that math ourselves internally, we see our Industrial business in Q2 down low single digits, right? So it is down a little bit year-over-year, but it's low single digits. So from that point of view, I think, it's a little bit different than maybe the math that you did, but understand it's difficult for you to be able to do that math. When we look at it, it is the broad-based business. Some of that does get included in factory automation, and that may be our speculation as Tunç indicated, maybe just some latency on some of these CapEx projects on the factory automation side. But again, that's just what we've heard from a couple of our customers who then sell into China. So it's tough for us to know. But overall, we are seeing the slowdown in Industrial. We do see that's kind of down year-over-year in Q2 at around kind of low single digits. And that was after, again, it kind of held up in the first quarter, kind of growing 12% year-over-year.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Chris Danely with Citi.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Chris Danely with Citi.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Could you just talk about where you first saw the weakness either by end-market or geography? And then where have you seen the weakness most recently?
componenttext: Could you just talk about where you first saw the weakness either by end-market or geography? And then where have you seen the weakness most recently?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take that. It's difficult to parse that out. I mean, again, it was in industrial. As we said, it was sort of near towards the end of the quarter when we started to see that. And it was broad-based, across all the geographies. So I wouldn't say i
componenttext: Yes, I'll take that. It's difficult to parse that out. I mean, again, it was in industrial. As we said, it was sort of near towards the end of the quarter when we started to see that. And it was broad-based, across all the geographies. So I wouldn't say it was -- we saw it in one area first or another area. So -- and it's still pretty early. And I think all of us are much better at accepting cycles backward looking. And I'm sure that will be true again through this cycle.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tore Svanberg with Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tore Svanberg with Stifel.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: So Tunç, when you talk to some of these factory automation customers, you mentioned that they're pausing up. Did you get a sense that they're kind of pausing to wait how the trade situation unfolds? Or are they now kind of looking at transferring manufac
componenttext: So Tunç, when you talk to some of these factory automation customers, you mentioned that they're pausing up. Did you get a sense that they're kind of pausing to wait how the trade situation unfolds? Or are they now kind of looking at transferring manufacturing out of China and, therefore, you're starting to see the pause? I'm just trying to understand how long this is going to last and I don't know if you have any color you could share with us.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll share with you what I know, which is not going to be a whole lot. Remember it's the automation customers, and we're talking about their comments about their customers. So it's really hard to understand. But it looked like they were mostly waiti
componenttext: Well, I'll share with you what I know, which is not going to be a whole lot. Remember it's the automation customers, and we're talking about their comments about their customers. So it's really hard to understand. But it looked like they were mostly waiting for, as you said, the trade situation or the tariff situation to resolve itself. But as we all know, it hasn't yet. And it is not really known how long it's going to take to resolve if ever, frankly. So it's not really that clear whether this will be just let's wait and then we'll build the factory somewhere else or let's wait and it get resolved. I think the world is continues to need products to buy. So I don't think that the long-term growth in factory automation or productivity increases are going to change. So the demand is going to be there. But right now, I think a lot of customers are kind of in a let's wait and see before you make big decisions mode. But I don't -- I think that fundamentally does not change our belief that automation is going to be a great area for growth for Maxim for years to come.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: This is Bruce. I actually just want to clarify something that came up with the earlier question on the AR. We're close to it, so I just assumed people knew. But just to make sure there's a clarification there. There's an accounting change that went into e
componenttext: This is Bruce. I actually just want to clarify something that came up with the earlier question on the AR. We're close to it, so I just assumed people knew. But just to make sure there's a clarification there. There's an accounting change that went into effect in our -- beginning our first quarter of fiscal year where basically we used to report in the accounts receivable line, that used to be net of any reserves associated with that. And so the accounting change now moved that reserve down into the liability side. So now you're seeing gross AR. And so if you're just looking at that, and you have to -- if you don't grab the reserves that are down in the liability section, then absolutely it will look very large. So you have to do an adjusted DSO calculation. I'm sorry, about that. But just to get an apples-to-apples comparison. So anyway, so I just wanted to clarify that point. That said, we still, even on an adjusted basis, we've seen some increase in our DSO, and we're working to bring that down. But certainly, if you haven't made that adjustment, it would look much worse than it really is. So again, I apologize, but I just wanted to clarify that.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, just for everybody to know, I mean, our terms have not changed with customers. And we're collecting as aggressively as we always have been. So nothing's changed in the fundamentals.
componenttext: Yes, just for everybody to know, I mean, our terms have not changed with customers. And we're collecting as aggressively as we always have been. So nothing's changed in the fundamentals.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Toshiya Hari with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Toshiya Hari with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could provide a little bit more color on your Consumer business. It seems like you had a pretty good quarter in September. It seems like you're guiding to a seasonal December quarter. But curious what kind of trends -- what kind of moment
componenttext: I was hoping you could provide a little bit more color on your Consumer business. It seems like you had a pretty good quarter in September. It seems like you're guiding to a seasonal December quarter. But curious what kind of trends -- what kind of momentum did you see in your large smartphone customer? What are your expectations with that customer going into December and, perhaps, into the early part of 2019? And other parts of consumer, where I think you've done a great job in diversifying your application in customer mix over the past couple of years, how sustainable is growth in that business over the next year or so? You guys talked about wearables, tablets, gaming. Wearables and tablets aren't necessarily growthy markets, if you will. And in gaming, I think one of your larger customers just had a very huge product cycle. So curious how you think about sustainability there.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, so actually you answered most of the questions yourself, which is great. So our strategy has been, as you will put, to diversify the consumer business and to broaden both the customers, the markets we're getting into and the types of products that we
componenttext: Yes, so actually you answered most of the questions yourself, which is great. So our strategy has been, as you will put, to diversify the consumer business and to broaden both the customers, the markets we're getting into and the types of products that we sell. And we've made good headway in that, that we have a broader customer base. And we are selling into all the markets you mentioned, into tablets, wearables, some gaming products, many other broad-based applications. So that is going well. With our largest customer, obviously, we still have a good relationship. We have -- the plant is still continuing to make smartphones. So we'll have some business there in the company. But always remember that our philosophy here is to broaden that business as much as we can, which gives us more stability and less changes from year-to-year. And also make sure that our goals to have a business that we can rely on, in terms of cash flows, is going to be there. So I think, we've made great progress. We've been reporting about it for a while now. And to your questions about the largest customer, the relationship is good. It's very healthy. And as we do each year, we have to win the business every year. And that, for that market, does not change.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's Bruce. This is Bruce. Just to add on to what Tunç said, while that relationship with our large customer is good, we still expect that customer to be less than 10% for this fiscal year. And then also, just to reiterate what Tunç said, I think i
componenttext: Yes, it's Bruce. This is Bruce. Just to add on to what Tunç said, while that relationship with our large customer is good, we still expect that customer to be less than 10% for this fiscal year. And then also, just to reiterate what Tunç said, I think it's important for people to understand, with this broad-based business, they're all kind of small wins. And yes, we're going to win and lose some of those, but to the extent that we continue to kind of leverage our power management, our audio products across this broad base, we think that's what allows us to deliver sort of this very broad-based stable consumer business. And as we said, even with the second quarter seasonally down, we still expect it to be up in sort of the low- to mid-single digits year-over-year. So I think that's just evidence of kind of the transformation we've done within our Consumer business.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of CJ Muse with Evercore.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of CJ Muse with Evercore.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: I guess two-part question. First one, are you seeing stronger dollar weakening emerging currencies as a headwind? Have customers discussed that? And then secondly, as you think about the higher tax rate versus that 9% to 10% you're thinking before, is tha
componenttext: I guess two-part question. First one, are you seeing stronger dollar weakening emerging currencies as a headwind? Have customers discussed that? And then secondly, as you think about the higher tax rate versus that 9% to 10% you're thinking before, is that a function of more U.S. revenues expected in the mix in fiscal '19? And should we think about that 9% to 10% as we move into fiscal '20?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sure, so the first question on the currency, 99% of our revenue is in dollars. And so, from that point of view, we have -- that doesn't impact us and even for customers that translate like some of our distribution partners, that currency has not come up.
componenttext: Sure, so the first question on the currency, 99% of our revenue is in dollars. And so, from that point of view, we have -- that doesn't impact us and even for customers that translate like some of our distribution partners, that currency has not come up. So we don't see that as an issue for us. On the tax side, the reason it came in at 13% versus our guidance of 9% to 10%, when we guided in July, it was based on our best understanding of kind of the new tax reform laws. The IRS subsequently released kind of proposed rules in September that countered some of our assumptions. And then we ended up at around 13%. We do expect that 13% based on what we know is kind of the best estimate to use for modeling going forward. And it was really about just learning, getting all the rules out there. It wasn't about mix of our business or anything related to operational aspects of the business.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: One other thing on the currency aspect, as Bruce said, most of our sales are in dollars, so it doesn't matter for us. But obviously, changes in currencies of different countries do affect the sales of their end products to their customers and their compet
componenttext: One other thing on the currency aspect, as Bruce said, most of our sales are in dollars, so it doesn't matter for us. But obviously, changes in currencies of different countries do affect the sales of their end products to their customers and their competitiveness. However, Maxim's a global company, so we're pretty much selling to all these customers. So who wins or loses doesn't affect us that much. So this is really not on our radar as a concern or something to think about.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Chris Caso with Raymond James.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Chris Caso with Raymond James.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Just a question with respect to guidance and how much of -- within that guidance, the weakness you're attributing to end demand as compared to inventory? And I know that, that is probably easier to answer with respect to the distribution channel at  end-m
componenttext: Just a question with respect to guidance and how much of -- within that guidance, the weakness you're attributing to end demand as compared to inventory? And I know that, that is probably easier to answer with respect to the distribution channel at  end-market customers. You said I think that the distributor inventory was 63 days, which is ahead of your target. How fast do you expect to get that within your target levels and how much of a headwind does that present?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Certainly, we're committed to our target of 60 days or less, and we're always working to achieve that. I would say the biggest wild card for us on that is resales, right? And the ability to forecast that, especially when we're still kind of in early days
componenttext: Certainly, we're committed to our target of 60 days or less, and we're always working to achieve that. I would say the biggest wild card for us on that is resales, right? And the ability to forecast that, especially when we're still kind of in early days of the softness that we're seeing. So it's difficult for us to predict, say this quarter, on where channel inventory will be. Absolutely, our commitment over the long term, medium term is to get that number to 60 or less. And we absolutely will get there, so certainly that's something we'll report every quarter, and you can track our progress against that.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: So I guess if I hear this correctly, you guys are talking about the slowdown really being more or less Industrial-centric at this point. So I'm wondering if you kind of just think back to the past cycles in '13 and '15, is it rare for a correction to be h
componenttext: So I guess if I hear this correctly, you guys are talking about the slowdown really being more or less Industrial-centric at this point. So I'm wondering if you kind of just think back to the past cycles in '13 and '15, is it rare for a correction to be happening in just 1 end market versus perhaps spread into other segments? If you could just maybe help me understand your conviction on how this is Industrial-specific versus the risk they have with respect to other markets. And then how would you react if this is a more widespread correction across different end markets?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, so as you pointed out, we've obviously been through a few of these cycles before. And what I can say is my experience has been that each one of them is a little bit different than the previous one. So it's too early to compare or build a model saying
componenttext: Yes, so as you pointed out, we've obviously been through a few of these cycles before. And what I can say is my experience has been that each one of them is a little bit different than the previous one. So it's too early to compare or build a model saying the cycle looks like the previous one. So let me just make sure that's clear. The things that we do know is that since we've been through a few of them, both Bruce and I, we know how to manage through these cycles. We know what to do in terms of making sure the company does well. Compared to prior cycles, I think Maxim is much better able to be successful, mainly because we're more diversified in our revenue base. We have a better profitability model and our gross margins are much less sensitive to volume. Now your question about, will it spread to other areas from Industrial, yes, some background sound there which...

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: If the caller could...
componenttext: If the caller could...

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, mute.
componenttext: Yes, mute.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Mute.
componenttext: Mute.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: All right, thanks. So in terms of will it spread into other market, it's really difficult for us to assess that. But the important thing to realize is that a bigger portion of our small customer, broad customer revenue is coming from our industrial custom
componenttext: All right, thanks. So in terms of will it spread into other market, it's really difficult for us to assess that. But the important thing to realize is that a bigger portion of our small customer, broad customer revenue is coming from our industrial customers. So there's fewer revenue that's going through small customers in other markets, frankly. So that's one point. And the other one that I think most people have already heard about is unit sales of cars, that's kind of slowed down a little bit. But we're -- as I said, we're pretty immune to that one. So I think that we'll be doing fine in that area. So hard for us to predict, and each cycle is a little bit different. But I think we'll do well in the cycle if it extends or gets more concerning or more.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: And this is Bruce, just to add on, exactly what Tunç said, it's always difficult to predict. But as he said, I think we're much better positioned to do well. And I think our strong cash position, strong cash flow going forward really allows us to increas
componenttext: And this is Bruce, just to add on, exactly what Tunç said, it's always difficult to predict. But as he said, I think we're much better positioned to do well. And I think our strong cash position, strong cash flow going forward really allows us to increase our buyback during this period and really buy back our shares and potentially a weak environment which we think is, by far, the best investment of our cash. And absolutely, we believe we'll come out stronger on the back end of this cycle. However, long it lasts because of the strength of our business model, the strength of our cash flow and our commitment to use that to invest in Maxim because we believe that this is the company with a very strong long-term value proposition.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Srini Pajjuri with Macquarie.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Srini Pajjuri with Macquarie.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Bruce, I have a question. I want to go back to the inventory comment. So as you bring down your channel inventory, could you talk about what your plans are for your own balance sheet inventory? And it looks like you're bring that down as well. My question
componenttext: Bruce, I have a question. I want to go back to the inventory comment. So as you bring down your channel inventory, could you talk about what your plans are for your own balance sheet inventory? And it looks like you're bring that down as well. My question is does it make more sense to actually carry a bit more inventory on your own balance sheet as opposed to in the channel given the environment? And then, if you were to bring down your own balance sheet inventory, how much of a headwind is that to your gross margins and how should we think about it?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sure. And I think most people who know me know I hate inventory. I just think it's a result of inefficiencies in the supply chain. And what we've done is by moving to a flexible manufacturing strategy, I think we have that ability to react both on the ups
componenttext: Sure. And I think most people who know me know I hate inventory. I just think it's a result of inefficiencies in the supply chain. And what we've done is by moving to a flexible manufacturing strategy, I think we have that ability to react both on the upside and the downside to changes in demand. And so absolutely, I think we got a little bit ahead of ourselves when we got to 127 days last quarter, and I stated that very clearly. And we're committed to bringing that down. We brought it down 3 days this quarter to 124 and, absolutely, our goal, if you look at our internal plans, are to continue bringing that number down regardless of the demand environment. And because of that flexible manufacturing strategy, we don't expect that will be a big headwind on gross margin. Obviously, there's some. I had said kind of publicly in prior occasions that we did sensitivity analysis, and we said that there was a 10% decline in revenue. It might be a 1% to 2% impact on the gross margin. And here, you can see in this quarter we're down about 7.5% sequentially, and we're seeing about a 1 point impact to gross margin as a result of that. So overall, we feel like the strategy we undertook a few years ago when we transferred the company, it's the right strategy throughout a cycle, both good and bad. And we feel comfortable with that. And we're absolutely committed to bringing down inventory, both off our balance sheet and within the channel.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Christopher Rolland with Susquehanna.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: As we look at semis guides this season, we're getting a pretty big difference between companies. And it seems like those companies that were kind of notorious for longer lead times are guiding better and those with shorter lead times, like you guys or TI,
componenttext: As we look at semis guides this season, we're getting a pretty big difference between companies. And it seems like those companies that were kind of notorious for longer lead times are guiding better and those with shorter lead times, like you guys or TI, let's say, are having a little bit more challenging 4Q. And I guess I'm wondering those with short lead times like yourself, do you think maybe you guys are taking lumps a quarter earlier than the others or perhaps just a correlation to lead times is more of a coincidence? Just any thoughts you guys might have there would be great.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's probably a good model to build after the cycle was over, but we don't really have enough insights into how the companies that are working down their longer lead times, when they get to see this versus those with short lead times. My intuition
componenttext: Yes, that's probably a good model to build after the cycle was over, but we don't really have enough insights into how the companies that are working down their longer lead times, when they get to see this versus those with short lead times. My intuition would say short lead time companies would probably see it quicker. But I don't have any data to back that up.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Cody Acree with Loop Capital.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Cody Acree with Loop Capital.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Bruce, with your 63 days of channel inventory and your target of less than 60, do you get a sense in talking to distributors that this is likely to linger into the March quarter? Or are you comfortable that just getting within that kind of 60-day range is
componenttext: Bruce, with your 63 days of channel inventory and your target of less than 60, do you get a sense in talking to distributors that this is likely to linger into the March quarter? Or are you comfortable that just getting within that kind of 60-day range is going to be a sufficient leanness of the channel inventory?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean it's very difficult for us to understand how long this will last. So I think, from that point of view, I don't think we have any unique insights there. We're just managing it based on what we're seeing and working to pay close attention to res
componenttext: Yes, I mean it's very difficult for us to understand how long this will last. So I think, from that point of view, I don't think we have any unique insights there. We're just managing it based on what we're seeing and working to pay close attention to resales and adjust shipment appropriately to find that right balance between supporting the appropriate level of inventories because, as I said, part of our distribution is supporting automotive, which is doing well, right? Part of it is supporting some of the similar broad-based consumer businesses that are doing well and so -- with the flipside being we need to closely manage the inventory for like the industrial and broad-based businesses. So we're trying to find that right balance while bringing it down to the 60 days. As I said, I think it's very difficult in the current flux of the current environment to predict exactly when that's going to happen. My commitment is we absolutely will continue to work on that and get to that level the exact quarter. So really depends on the environment and what happens with resales.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Just two somewhat housekeeping items. Bruce, you mentioned that the gross margin had some one-timers in the fiscal first quarter. I was hoping you could size that. And when you talk about OpEx controls, just talk about the availability of what you guys ca
componenttext: Just two somewhat housekeeping items. Bruce, you mentioned that the gross margin had some one-timers in the fiscal first quarter. I was hoping you could size that. And when you talk about OpEx controls, just talk about the availability of what you guys can do in OpEx if revenue does get worse as we head into the first half of calendar '19?

headline: Maxim Integrated Products, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ross, so the onetime benefit was about 50 bps so of that 68, 5 about 50 bps was the onetime and then to go from the 68 to the 67 the midpoint of our guide is sort of that 1 point that I talked about around the revenue impact. Concerning OpEx, clearly
componenttext: Yes. Ross, so the onetime benefit was about 50 bps so of that 68, 5 about 50 bps was the onetime and then to go from the 68 to the 67 the midpoint of our guide is sort of that 1 point that I talked about around the revenue impact. Concerning OpEx, clearly, we've said that we're going to keep it flat in the second quarter. And that's despite -- it's about a $3.5 million impact of our annual salary adjustments that happen in the September quarters and that you get a full quarter impact. So we're already offsetting that number in the quarter. And we'll do our normal -- we look at kind of the discretionary spending first, right, incremental headcount add, travel, if this extends over time. Tunç and I have been through these cycles many times, we have the playbook. We know exactly how to work through that. So we're confident that we'll be able to manage OpEx appropriately. I do want to say, we'll make sure we continue to invest in those important businesses for us, right, the high growth areas that we've talked about, whether that's automotive, factory automation, the data center broad-based consumer. But that said, within a large company, there are always opportunities to manage our cost appropriately. And I think, over the years, we've shown that we're pretty good managers in that area.
